Answer Methods#

Module that houses a class that encompasses all the methods thatâ€™ll create the answers to the questionnaire questions.

class service_monitoring.answer_methods.Answers(drop, units)[source]#

This class houses all the actions that the user chooses. Each one is a command to be executed or a script to be run. It needs two values to be instantiated:

Parameters:

  • drop (str) â€“ What application do we want to use?

  • units (str) â€“ Chooses what method to implement.

active_nodes()[source]#

How many Celery active nodes are there now?

Requires a drop value.

This method runs the following Celery command:

celery -A <application_name> inspect active
stats()[source]#

Show Celery workers statistics.

Requires a drop value.

This method runs the following Celery command:

celery -A <application_name> inspect stats
reports()[source]#

Returns inspect report value.

Requires a drop value.

This method runs the following Celery command:

celery -A <application_name> inspect report
events()[source]#

See Celery remote control events.

Requires a drop value.

This method runs the following Celery command:

celery -A <application_name> control events -d
clock()[source]#

Sees clock of Celeryâ€™s workers.

Requires a drop value.

This method runs the following Celery command:

celery -A <application_name> inspect clock
scheduled()[source]#

See worker that are seconds away of starting a task.

Requires a drop value.

This method runs the following Celery command:

celery -A <application_name> inspect scheduled
timers()[source]#

Shows active Systemd timers. This method runs the following command:

sudo systemctl --no-pager list-timers
active_services()[source]#

Shows active Systemd services.

This method runs the following command:

sudo systemctl --no-pager --type=service
service_status()[source]#

See Systemd services status.

Requires a unit value.

This method runs the following command:

sudo systemctl --no-pager status <service>
service_logs()[source]#

See logs for specific Systemd services.

Variables:

choice (str) â€“ User input. Asks if he wants to see the services belonging to the current unit value.

If yes, it runs the following command:

sudo SYSTEMD_COLORS=1 journalctl | grep <service>

If no, it assumes the user wants to have a general view of the processes, and runs the command:

sudo SYSTEMD_COLORS=1 journalctl | grep python3
stop_service()[source]#

Stops execution of Systemd services.

Requires a unit value.

Runs the following command:

sudo systemctl stop <service>
start_service()[source]#

Starts Systemd service.

Requires a unit value.

Runs the following command:

sudo systemctl start <service>
daemon_reload()[source]#

Reloads the daemons of all services and timers.

Necessary after any alteration to the Systemd services.

Runs the following command:

sudo systemctl daemon-reload
edit_service()[source]#

Stops the units, opens the service or timer in $EDITOR, reloads Systemmd daemon and restarts units.

Requires a unit value.

Runs the following commands in succession:

sudo systemctl stop <service>
sudo vim /usr/lib/systemd/system/<service>
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl start <service>
reset_failed()[source]#

After deleting units, run this command to have Systemd erase them.

If you donâ€™t, it will complain that it canâ€™t find the unit.

Runs the following command:

sudo systemctl reset-failed
delete_service()[source]#

  1. Stops the service.

  2. Disables it.

  3. Deletes files.

If service is completely erased, itâ€™ll delete also the entry on the json file and run again the dropdown creation file.

Variables:

  • decision (str) â€“

    User input. Confirms if he wants to delete the services belonging to current unit.

    If â€˜yesâ€™, appends service name to list.

    If â€˜noâ€™:

  • deci (str) â€“ User input. Asks what unit he wants to delete.

deci appends new choice to list. If no choice was made, the program exits.

For each service in the list, these commands are run:

sudo systemctl stop <service>
sudo systemctl disable <service>
sudo trash /usr/lib/systemd/system/<service>
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl reset-failed

The dropdown_info.json file is updated with the deletion of the service.

create_service()[source]#

Searches for files with the prefix service or timer on the current working directory. If it finds them, it asks if these are the files to be used.

Variables:

  • use_choice (str) â€“ User choice. Do you want to use <service>? If yes, it runs the method, if no, it will copy a default service file to cwd and open it as, <current_dir>.service, to create a new service.

  • unit_making (str) â€“ User choice. What unit do you want to create? Service, Timer or both?

Runs the following commands:

sudo vim <service_name>.service
sudo vim <service_name>.timer

These files, pre-built or freshly generated, will be:

  1. Copied to the services folder:

    sudo cp <service> /usr/lib/systemd/system

  2. Sent the daemon-reload command:

    sudo systemctl daemon-reload

  3. Services are startted:

    sudo systemctl start <service>

  4. Their status checked, to see it they are loaded:

    sudo systemctl <service> status

This new service will be manually added to the json file and the dropdown file updated.
